title: Permit multiple urls for a single version of a package
body:
Right now we can associate a single `url` and a single checksum with each version of a package. This proposal aims at extending the `version` directive so that we can associate multiple archives with a single version, based on a constraint.

### Rationale

Currently Spack doesn't support neatly the versioning of third-party binary packages that come with different archives for different architectures or configurations. 

One example that was discussed a while ago is `cudnn`, see #5980. In that case the binary package to be downloaded for a given version of `cudnn` depends on the version of `cuda` being used. Another that came up recently is #11198, where there are multiple versions of the Arm toolsuite depending on the OS and platform a user is targeting.

This proposal aims at extending the `version` directive so that we'll not be forced to add an extra suffix to the available versions in order to work around this issue.

### Description

As the checksum and url of a package are used **after** the recipe has been concretized, the version directive could be extended like:
```python
version("19.0.3", url=urls_for_multiple_archives()
    .when(
        'arch=linux-rhel6-x86_64', 
        sha256="0ace88a1847d8f622f077cd38fa9dddf7f2d6dd6aad086be0e0a66e10fb8b64b",
        url="http://content.allinea.com/downloads/arm-forge-19.0.3-Redhat-6.0-x86_64.tar"
    ).when(
        'arch=linux-rhel7-x86_64', 
￼        sha256="35c7a9532aa19251343c37b8f5eb51ef04f7b6e8b42bea2bd932f4d83a1e8375",
￼        url="http://content.allinea.com/downloads/arm-forge-19.0.3-Redhat-7.0-x86_64.tar",
    )
)
```
When installing the package the constraints should be checked - in the same order they are written to avoid ambiguities - and the first match should be considered the one to be used.

### Additional information
The directive tries to use a fluent interface for these complex cases, to maintain it declarative as was done for the multi-variant case #9481 - name of the helper functions etc. are tentative.
